title: Bribery Quiz
description: For each bribery charge, guess who committed it: An Olympics official, a FIFA official, a congressman, or a dictator.

questions.content: Was filmed by undercover investigators asking for an $800,000 bribe for a personal construction project.
questions.feedback: Former FIFA executive committee member Amos Adamu was filmed soliciting a bribe in exchange for his World Cup vote in a sting operation by the Sunday Times of London in 2010.

questions.content: Allegedly attempted to obtain an honorary knighthood as a bribe.
questions.feedback: Former FIFA executive committee member Nicolás Leoz is alleged to have solicited a knighthood in exchange for backing England’s bid to host the 2018 World Cup.

questions.content: Accepted the free use of a yacht, a used Rolls-Royce, antique furniture, Persian rugs, jewelry, and a $2,000 contribution for his daughter's college graduation party. Also, allegedly accepted the services of prostitutes as a bribe.
questions.feedback: Rep. Randy “Duke” Cunningham (R-Calif.) accepted multiple favors from defense contractors prior to resigning from office and pleading guilty to bribery, fraud, and tax evasion charges in 2005.

questions.content: Allegedly accepted the services of prostitutes, paid by credit card, as a bribe.
questions.feedback: Members of the Salt Lake City Olympic bid committee allegedly charged escort services for International Olympic Committee officials to their credit cards.

questions.content: A business associate placed a single deposit of more than $3 million in a bank account set up in his daughter’s name. Daughter was 10 years old at the time.
questions.feedback: Former FIFA executive committee member Ricardo Teixeira had more than $3 million paid to his 10-year-old daughter’s bank account in 2011, allegedly by former FC Barcelona President Sandro Rosell, whose club had six months earlier agreed to a sponsorship deal with the Qatar Foundation. Michael Garcia, the joint chief investigator of FIFA’s ethics committee, is reportedly scrutinizing Teixeira’s decision to support Qatar’s World Cup bid.

questions.content: Allegedly set up a dummy bank account as a Haitian earthquake fund and stole from said account.
questions.feedback: Former FIFA Vice President Jack Warner was allegedly responsible for emergency aid monies that suspiciously went missing.

questions.content: Accepted a bribe of cosmetic surgery to smooth bags under eyes.
questions.feedback: An International Olympics Committee member received free cosmetic surgery, courtesy of Salt Lake City Olympic organizers.

questions.content: Accepted knee surgery as a bribe.
questions.feedback: An International Olympics Committee member received a new knee joint, courtesy of Salt Lake Olympic organizers.

questions.content: Attended a lavish, illicit party at Neville Chamberlain’s old house in Birmingham, England, where kimono-clad women reportedly served sushi.
questions.feedback: Olympic officials reportedly had quite a party with the Nagano, Japan, bid committee in June 1991 prior to the IOC meeting to determine the location of the 1998 Olympics. Olympic regulations prohibited parties during IOC meetings.

questions.content: Considered offering $1.6 billion to buy Manchester United, but decided it might “look bad.”
questions.feedback: In January 2009, Myanmarese dictator Than Shwe figured it was a bad time for a $1 billion-plus soccer team purchase, considering that the country, also known as Burma, was still struggling to recover from the damage inflicted by Cyclone Nargis only a few months before.

questions.content: Was filmed by investigators accepting $100,000 in bribes. Kept $90,000 in marked money in his office freezer.
questions.feedback: In 2005, federal agents found $90,000 in Rep. William Jefferson’s (D-La.) freezer.

questions.content: Used influence of alleged Uzbek mafia boss and heroin kingpin to secure massive international contract.
questions.feedback: The head of the Russian Olympic bid committee publicly thanked alleged Uzbek heroin trafficker Gafur Rakhimov for his assistance in winning the 2014 Winter Games for Sochi.

questions.content: Once a youth organizer for Spain’s fascists, he liked to be called “your excellency.” He was the boss of a corrupt organization for 21 years.
questions.feedback: Juan Antonio Samaranch was president of the International Olympic Committee from 1980 to 2001. During his tenure, the organization faced scandal after scandal.
